titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Sterling Lord Archive
1946-1998
MSS 058
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Laura Newsome, 2013.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-11-27T15:17-0500

did.abstract: Sterling Lord founded the Sterling Lord Agency in 1952 (later to become Sterling Lord Literistic). He has worked with well-known writers, such as Jack Kerouac, Ken Kesey, Anne Sexton, and the Berenstains. This collection contains Lord’s professional papers, including financial records, contracts, correspondence, and subject files for the many authors he has worked with.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains records created by Sterling Lord and the Sterling Lord Literistic Agency, including correspondence, manuscripts, photographs, promotional material, contracts, personnel files and financial records. The bulk of the collection comprises subject files of the authors who were managed by Sterling Lord and others at the agency. The collection covers a brief period of time before Sterling Lord founded the agency, and throughout the agency’s operation, up to 1998.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Sterling Lord Archive; MSS 058; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into three series:

list.item: Series II: Financial, Administrative, and Legal

arrangement.p: Series I, Subseries A: General subject files, is arranged chronologically by year, and alphabetically within each year. The rest of the collection is arranged alphabetically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Permission to access the collection must be granted by the collection donor. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Sterling Lord Archive was donated to NYU Libraries by Sterling Lord in two sections, in 1969 and 2010.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Sterling Lord was born in Burlington, Iowa in 1920. He had an interest in tennis from a young age, and in high school became involved in sports journalism, calling in tennis scores to the local newspapers, and writing for his school newspaper. Lord’s passion for tennis brought him to Grinnell College in Iowa. After college, he was drafted into the army, where he studied electronics and radar. Lord was then shipped to Europe. At the end of WWII, Lord started working for the European edition of “Stars and Stripes”, an army publication. There he became the editor for “Weekend”, a weekly magazine, which was shortly thereafter shut down by the army. Lord and Richard Evan Jones, the editor in chief, kept the magazine printing as a private enterprise. They had an office in Frankfurt, and later in Paris, where Lord met his wife, artist Dodie Yencesse. “Weekend” eventually folded in the late 1940’s, and Lord decided to move to New York City.

During his first two years in New York, Lord worked as an editor for three different magazines. He decided that the magazine industry was too unstable, and that he wanted to be a literary agent. Lord opened up a literary agency with partner Stanley Colbert in 1952. After a couple of years, Colbert left the agency and in 1954 it became the Sterling Lord Agency. During the early years of the agency, Lord mostly managed non-fiction and ghost writers, such as Charlie Samuels, John Keats, Rowland Barker and Al Hirshberg. That was also the period when he met, and started working with, Jack Kerouac. The agency grew quickly as Lord, and the authors he published, made names for themselves.

In 1987, Sterling Lord Agency merged with the firm Literistic, and has since continued to serve the literary community. Throughout the years, the Sterling Lord Literistic Agency has managed many well known and respected authors, such as Terry Southern, David Wise, Jimmy Breslin, Anne Sexton, Erica Jong, the Berenstain family, and many others.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains the subject files kept by the Sterling Lord Literistic Agency. These files consist of correspondence of agents with authors and publishers. They also contain manuscripts, photographs, promotional material, and all other items associated with the authors being managed by the agency. Subseries A contains the general subject files. These are described at the box level. Subseries B contains subject files that had been removed by the agency, grouping the materials of specific authors together. There is still material from these authors in the general subject files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the general subject files from the Sterling Lord Archive. It includes correspondence files with authors, publishers, and agents, and other general subject files kept by Sterling Lord and other agents at the Sterling Lord Literistic Agency.

scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files on authors, publishers, and agents at the Sterling Lord Literistic Agency. These files were separated from the general subject files by the agency.

Series II: Financial, Administrative, and Legal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains all financial, administrative and legal papers from Sterling Lord and the Sterling Lord Literistic Agency. Subseries A, the administrative and legal files, contain contracts, personnel files, and other material relating to the administration of the agency. Subseries B, the financial files, contains bank statements, cancelled checks, royalty statements, budget reports, and all other financial material.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Administrative and Legal papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Several of the files in this series had ID numbers with the folder titles [STER-xxx]. There was no apparent order to these numbers. The folders have been arranged alphabetically, but the ID numbers have been maintained in the title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains the administrative and legal papers from the Sterling Lord Literistic Agency. It includes contracts for films and merchandising, legal correspondence and case files, calendars, log books, and all other material related to the administration of the agency.
